positive.review:
This War of Mine-like game which feels a little barebones atm but could have great potential in the future

pros:
- Gameplay loop is really fun and the combat/exploration is a lot less janky than it was in TWoM
- Cool colourful artstyle that nails the 80s vibes
- Actually pretty challenging as even 2 zombies at once can get you killed or infected
- Has some real spooky easter eggs and discoveries that will catch you out the first time

cons:
- Base management is more streamlined and annoying to use compared to TWoM. You have to rotate through every survivor and manually control them with WASD to go to their work station every time. You can't place objects and workstations where you'd like, they're predefined, so it never feels like 'your base.' 
This is worsened by the fact the game forces you to move bases periodically. Lack of stuff like temperature management, radio announcements or visitors makes this part of the game really easy and just something you try to speedrun through to get to the fun part.

- A little too sandboxy and gamey. You never feel forced to make hard decisions or have to adapt because you can just go wherever you want every single playthrough, so the world doesn't feel alive. TWoM would force you to make choices like robbing an elderly couple or risking your life sneaking into a military base, this game just lets you scavenge for fun and at your own pace.

- Doesn't make enough use of the zombie/horror stuff. Stuff like the [spoiler]meat factory[/spoiler] is really good and there should be more of that in the game. Infection never feels like a serious risk and you can tank hits from zombies, really needs an armour system.
We have to make it through the night, as quietly as we can. One wrong move, and the whole city wakes.

The game is fun, the initial creep factor does stick well with well developed zombies and environments, the character & need management is simple and intuitive, and each level/location is well made. However, the game suffers from a lack of replayability as the map itself is static and the (now) 3 escape plans are fixed/linear.

The game would benefit greatly from the incorporation of roguelite mechanics to change up the 'world' map, as well as key item and survivor locations for every new playthrough. As of now, I think I've played through each escape plan the 2 different ways each one can be completed (all in 25 hours apparently) and now I'm having a hard time getting myself to play it more; because it feels 'solved'.

As a rule of thumb, horror does not mix well with repetition, to maintain that creep/fear factor there was to be a balance between perceived challenge and novelty. This game nails the former but suffers from the latter.

And since the city is big and the devs active, we can imagine a good complement of places with more scenarios, characters... in a close future. Some cliches of the genre are still missing, there is room for nice added content.

I have not much negative things to say. Really. I just had a good time.

Instead of criticism, I am going to pinpoint a short list of things that could be improved since it is an E.A:
. My first concern is the visibility when everyone is occupied (or not) before leaving the base. The little grey message box is not really pleasant or easy to read. Nothing really problematic indeed. But having the list of characters on the right instead of the left would make this information more obvious.
 . Stealth kill in a door frame or close can be painful at time. The character closing the door instead of killing the Z and now facing it for a direct fight that would wake up more...
. The time to reach the level 3 of devices, such as the kitchen plan, there is likely no more use of it anymore. Meat already became extremely rare... I think this may be rebalanced. Or it serves another type of game I did not see yet. I ended the game with +50 cooked meals in advance and no meat in any of them. Most of the places were empty.
. I would have expected more of a story at the end. [spoiler] Especially among the remaining characters. I finished with 4 and one from the start was no more. [/spoiler] A more personalized ending depending on who survived, in what condition, where they go... Here it is too much, you finished following that path, goodbye. Characters are ignored. There is no nice visual, video, whatsoever, or even just a contextual text that could have been appreciated.

That is all for my 2 cts of comments if any game dev read it.

Yet, the best Z game of that type I have played in years.

I really like this genre and will compare it to This War of Mine, since they are very similar but differ in a few ways:
Pros
- Moving from shelter to shelter to continue the main quest. Interesting gameplay mechanic. Much better than the classic survival in the same house for a set number of days.
- Clues found around the house open up subquests that inspire the player to explore everything.
Cons
- It doesn't have a strong soundtrack, which makes the atmosphere too calm.
- Having pistols or rifles is completely useless (at least as far as I've gotten with the story) because the game forces you to always opt for silent weapons or avoid confrontations.
- There are currently no achievements.

Overall, I was positively impressed for being in Early Access. Great job!

Holy cow, this thing isn't just good; it's the kind of groovy that'll make you toss your boomstick in the air and shout. If the video game industry had any brains, this atmospheric masterpiece would be the additional pillar for every Indie-AA studio out there. It’s like some genius Frankenstein'd the tense, 2D platforming desperation of [b]Deadlight[/b] with the resource management and gut-punch survival of [b]State of Decay[/b]. 

The visuals are slick and the sound design is so heavy it makes these deadites feel genuinely terrifying, right down to their shuffling feet. And here’s the real kicker: this is just Early Access, yet the campaign is already packed with more survival content than most finished AAA titles. You gotta manage your tiny group of survivors, scavenge for parts, and make brutal choices, each one leading to wildly different outcomes. I mean, multiple endings? That’s replay value, baby, and it’s done with serious style. 

Every run feels like a frantic dash for safety; it’s tense, it’s bloody, and it absolutely demands your attention, and remember: stay groovy.

I'm sure the developers are quite fatigued of hearing their game getting compared to “This War of Mine” and while I do see some similarities, I would argue that this game is the spiritual successor to the old flash game series “The Last Stand: Union City” by Con Artist Productions. I had sunken countless hours into Union City on Newgrounds due the fun gameplay and exploration of the city map. To me, it was one of the best Flash games created. Unfortunately, ever since flash was shut down I had always wanted to play a zombie game that brought back the thrill and exploration Union City gave me, but with more mechanical depth than a simple free Flash game.
 Honestly, “Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days” brought me an experience I’ve earned for over a decade. From the massive map with distinct locations, to the different survivors you can encounter, to even base management at different shelters, and the multiple endings each playthrough gives the player, there's a lot that can go on each playthrough. The developers have brought in a ton of entertaining concepts and made them into an enjoyable game. The fact this game is still being developed shows how far they have advanced with their game, especially with the game getting more monthly updates to bring new things for the players.

I don’t expect this review to relate to everybody, however “Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days” fulfilled a zombie survival sidescroller with a ton more depth with a distinct identity that took the best parts from Union city and made it grander. (Oh as a sidenote, unlike in The Last Stand: Union city, you won’t have to brace yourself for a horde of zombies crashing out on top of you from every single ceiling in each building.

To the developers at PikPok, thank you for the creation of this delightful game!

Other reviews aren't lying, it's basically This War of Mine but with Zombies.

Its gameplay is pretty basic, but if you're into the whole base management, scrounging for supplies and having to take care of characters needs ( morale, food, sleep ) you'll really like it.

I'm still wrapping up my first run, but even on normal difficulty you'll have an abundance of supplies, to the point where you'll be stacked up on food and medicine even with 5 characters in your base. On top of that, there's also no (noteworthy) choice and/or consequence to your actions, except for maybe throwing out party members that you think are infected, or have bad character traits, so there's not a lot of 'urge' to be scanty with your inventory.

Certain levels have some pretty cool hidden areas or environmental components that induce things like a drop of morale or mental issues to your character. That's one of the few mechanics that actually makes a run or playthrough feel more unique, so it can definitely use more of this.

Characters do have quests tied to them, but they're generally over after visiting 2 or 3 places and clicking through some dialogue. I actually get quite bummed out when a character dies ( no safe system so dead = dead ), but other than these mini quests they don't have any life to them. I think making characters interact more with each other or giving them more personality will definitely help, as right now it's kinda immersion breaking when my sister or partner dies and I only get a 'grief trait' for like 3 days after which I'm fine again lol

Last but not least, it's still really janky. Dying because you messed up is one thing, dying ( and permanently losing a character ) because you wanted to stealth kill a zombie but the game decides you wanted to close a door is just frustrating.

All and all, very positive first impression. It's stil Early Access of course but if they keep implementing player feedback I can imagine this thing becoming really big in 2026!

Into the Dead – Darkest Days captures exactly what makes the franchise so addictive: fast tension, a gripping atmosphere, and that constant sense of danger that draws you in from the very first minutes. Visually, the game is impressive, with a dark, moody setting that fits the chaos of survival perfectly. The audio design—from sharp gunfire to the unsettling growls of nearby hordes—pushes the immersion even further.

The gameplay strikes a great balance between familiar Into the Dead action and new survival elements. Every run feels strategic and intense, and it’s clear the developers understand what the community values.

But… something’s missing

Even though the foundation is strong, the experience can feel a bit too closed at times. The lack of a more open ending—or a way to naturally continue your progress after key story moments—left me wanting more. Not because the content is lacking, but because the world they created begs to be explored further.

Still, plenty of confidence

Of course, this is Early Access, and that’s where the game really shines. Updates are consistent, communication is transparent, and the direction the developers are taking feels promising. The core is already solid, and it’s obvious this project is set to grow, evolve, and expand.

Final Verdict

Into the Dead – Darkest Days is already an impressive entry in the series. It’s atmospheric, thrilling, and full of potential. Yes, I miss an open ending or extended endgame options—but based on the current quality, I’m confident the team will address these areas as development continues.

A strong start with a very bright future.

Initial impressions after 3 hours of game play. This game is good. It has that one more turn (salvage run) feel. Plays great on the Steam Deck. Was up till 3am playing.

In my opinion there is one major issue, melee weapons durability. It sucks. Getting 2-3 uses out of weapon does not feel good as a player. Especially for knives, when you're doing stealth attacks. They should be getting dull and need sharpening not outright break. Sometimes I feel like game developers learned all the wrong lessons from games like Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom. Great games but they started this trend of terrible weapons durability.

I tried downloading a weapon durability mod, but the requirement (MelonLoader) keeps crashing the game, regardless if there is a mod installed or not. The least the developers could do is give us a game option or config file to adjust it ourselves.

Although I do recommend it, if you can stomach the melee weapons durability, I'm giving it a thumb down in hopes the developers see this and make adjustments.
